qas.question: What did Burke want the Whigs to condemn?
What did Burke publish on Aug 3, 1791?

answers.text: Appeal from the New to the Old Whigs

qas.question: Burke thought the French Revolution was against whose principles?
Burke attacked Whigs who supported what?
What did the Whig party want Burke to condemn?

plausible_answers.text: Appeal from the New to the Old Whigs

qas.question: What pamphlet did Fox publish in 3 August 1791?
When did Burke write that he wanted to represent the whole party?
What party did the French Revolution condemn?
Burke believe most party member agreed with which opponent?

context: Burke knew that many members of <b7_0>the Whig Party<b7_0/> did not share <b8_0>Fox<b8_0/>'s views and he wanted to provoke them into condemning <a0_0><b4_0>the French Revolution<b4_0/><a0_0/>. Burke wrote that he wanted to represent the whole Whig party "as tolerating, and by a toleration, countenancing those proceedings" so that he could "stimulate them to a public declaration of what every one of their acquaintance privately knows to be...their sentiments". Therefore, on <b6_0>3 August 1791<b6_0/> Burke published his <a1_0><b5_0>Appeal from the New to the Old Whigs<b5_0/><a1_0/>, in which he renewed his criticism of the radical revolutionary programmes inspired by <a3_0>the French Revolution<a3_0/> and attacked the Whigs who supported them, as holding principles contrary to those traditionally held by <a2_0>the Whig party<a2_0/>.
